title: Modeling a Non-Periodic Context - Quadratic Function

content.description:
<math alttext="t"> <mi>t</mi> </math>
 <math alttext="0"> <mn>0</mn> </math>
 <math alttext="35"><mn>35</mn></math>
 <math alttext="45"><mn>45</mn></math>

Number of Cones
 <math alttext="14"> <mn>14</mn> </math>
 <math alttext="57"><mn>57</mn></math>
 <math alttext="46"><mn>46</mn></math>

The table gives the number of ice cream cones sold by a food vendor. On the initial day (<math alttext="t equals 0"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>) when the vendor added ice cream cones to the menu, the vendor sold <math alttext="14"><mn>14</mn></math> ice cream cones. Thirty-five days later (<math alttext="t equals 35"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>35</mn></math>), the vendor sold <math alttext="57"><mn>57</mn></math> ice cream cones. Ten days after that (<math alttext="t equals 45"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>45</mn></math>), the vendor sold <math alttext="46"><mn>46</mn></math> ice cream cones. 

The number of ice cream cones sold can be modeled by the quadratic function <math alttext="I"><mi>I</mi></math> given by <math alttext="I open parentheses t close parentheses equals a t squared plus b t plus c"><mi>I</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math>, where <math alttext="I open parentheses t close parentheses"><mi>I</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced></math> is the number of ice cream cones sold on day <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>.
content.question:
Part A

(i) Use the given data to write three equations that can be used to find the values for constants <math alttext="a"><mi>a</mi></math>, <math alttext="b"><mi>b</mi></math>, and <math alttext="c"><mi>c</mi></math> in the expression for <math alttext="I open parentheses t close parentheses"><mi>I</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced></math>.

(ii) Find the values for <math alttext="a"><mi>a</mi></math>,  <math alttext="b"><mi>b</mi></math>, and <math alttext="c"><mi>c</mi></math> as decimal approximations.

frqParts.text:
Part A

(i) Use the given data to write three equations that can be used to find the values for constants <math alttext="a"><mi>a</mi></math>, <math alttext="b"><mi>b</mi></math>, and <math alttext="c"><mi>c</mi></math> in the expression for <math alttext="I open parentheses t close parentheses"><mi>I</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced></math>.

(ii) Find the values for <math alttext="a"><mi>a</mi></math>,  <math alttext="b"><mi>b</mi></math>, and <math alttext="c"><mi>c</mi></math> as decimal approximations.

Part B

(i) Use the given data to find the average rate of change of the number of ice cream cones sold, in cones per day, from <math alttext="t equals 35"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>35</mn></math> to <math alttext="t equals 45"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>45</mn></math> days. Express your answer as a decimal approximation. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(ii) Use the average rate of change found in part B (i) to estimate the number of ice cream cones sold on day <math alttext="t equals 40"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>40</mn></math>. Show the work that leads to your answer.

(iii) Compare the estimate found in part B (ii) to the value given by the model, <math alttext="I open parentheses 40 close parentheses"><mi>I</mi><mfenced><mn>40</mn></mfenced></math>. Using characteristics of the average rate of change and characteristics of the quadratic model, explain why the two estimates differ. Your explanation should include a reference to the graph of \(I\).

Part C

Explain how the range values of the function <math alttext="I"><mi>I</mi></math> should be limited by the context of the problem.

topic.text: 1.3: Rates of Change in Linear and Quadratic Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.B: Express functions, equations, or expressions in analytically equivalent forms that are useful in a given mathematical or applied context.
